factoid: Borís looked attentively and kindly at Natásha's eager face.
Borís did not reply.
Natásha said, 'Don't you want to? Well, then, come here.'
Natásha went further in among the plants and threw down the doll.
Natásha whispered, 'Closer, closer!'
Natásha caught the young officer by his cuffs.
A look of solemnity and fear appeared on Natásha's flushed face.
Natásha whispered, 'And me? Would you like to kiss me?'
Natásha glanced up at the young officer from under her brows.
Natásha smiled.
Natásha was almost crying from excitement.
Borís blushed.
Borís said, 'How funny you are!'
Borís bent down to Natásha.
Borís blushed even more.
Borís waited and did nothing.
Natásha jumped up onto a tub to be higher than Borís.
Natásha embraced Borís so that both of her slender bare arms clasped him above his neck.
Natásha tossed back her hair.
Natásha kissed Borís full on the lips.
Natásha slipped down among the flowerpots on the other side of the tubs.
Natásha stood, hanging her head.
Borís said, 'Natásha, you know that I love you, but...'
Natásha asked, 'You are in love with me?'
Borís replied, 'Yes, I am, but please don't let us do like that... In another four years, then I will ask for your hand.'
Natásha considered.
Natásha counted, 'Thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen,' on her slender little fingers.
Natásha said, 'All right! Then it's settled?'
A smile of joy and satisfaction lit up Natásha's eager face.
Borís replied, 'Settled!'
Natásha said, 'Forever?'
Natásha said, 'Till death itself?'
Natásha took Borís's arm.
Natásha had a happy face.
Natásha went with Borís into the adjoining sitting room.
The countess received visitors.
The countess was so tired that she gave orders to admit no more.
The porter was told to invite to dinner all who came 'to congratulate.'
The countess wished to have a tête-à-tête talk with Princess Anna Mikháylovna.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna had a tear-worn but pleasant face.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna drew her chair nearer to that of the countess.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna said, 'With you I will be quite frank.'
Princess Anna Mikháylovna said, 'There are not many left of us old friends!'
Princess Anna Mikháylovna said, 'That's why I so value your friendship.'
Princess Anna Mikháylovna looked at Véra.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna paused.
The countess pressed Véra's hand.
The countess said, 'Véra, how is it you have so little tact? Don't you see you are not wanted here? Go to the other girls, or...'
Véra smiled contemptuously.
Véra replied, 'If you had told me sooner, Mamma, I would have gone.'
Véra noticed two couples sitting, one pair at each window.
Véra stopped and smiled scornfully.
Sónya was sitting close to Nicholas.
Nicholas was copying out some verses for Sónya, the first he had ever written.
Borís and Natásha were at the other window.
Borís and Natásha ceased talking when Véra entered.
Sónya looked at Véra with a guilty, happy face.
Natásha looked at Véra with a guilty, happy face.
It was pleasant and touching to see the little girls in love.
The sight of the little girls in love roused no pleasant feeling in Véra.
The countess said, 'How often have I asked you not to take my things?'
The countess said, 'You have a room of your own.'
The countess took the inkstand from Nicholas.
Nicholas said, 'In a minute, in a minute,' and dipped his pen.
Véra said, 'You always manage to do things at the wrong time.'
Véra said, 'You came rushing into the drawing room so that everyone felt ashamed of you.'
No one replied to Véra.
The four simply looked at one another.
The countess lingered in the room with the inkstand in her hand.
The countess said, 'And at your age what secrets can there be between Natásha and Borís, or between you two? It's all nonsense!'
Natásha said, 'Now, Véra, what does it matter to you?' and spoke very gently.
The countess seemed that day to be more than ever kind and affectionate to everyone.
Véra said, 'Very silly.'
Véra said, 'I am ashamed of you.'
Véra said, 'Secrets indeed!'
Natásha answered, 'All have secrets of their own,' and got warmer.
The countess said, 'We don't interfere with you and Berg.'
